ResponsesInList.Title: Individualised file downloads
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have a class of 40 students and I want to provide each one of them with an individualised assignment handout in moodle. That is, each student should see  their own unique version of a handout pdf file when they click a link. I can upload all 40 versions of the assignment easily enough. The main problem is that I do not want each student to see or access the other students versions of the handout. In other words, each student should only see one version of the handout which is their own, and no one else's. is there anyway to do this? Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individualised file downloads
ResponsesInList.Text: There is no simple way in core moodle. I think. The dialogue module May dpi it simplest. This is a plugin. -DereK.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Would like labels to be recurring each week and is it possible to duplicate content for courses without using import?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Coray Which Moodle version are you using. If you are using 2.x version you can duplicate the labels by clicking on the duplicate icon besides it  and then drag and drop in the appropriate sections where you want it. Second question- You can just backup the course and then restore it. Check http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Course_backup http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Course_restore

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating a resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Regarding the updating of a resource: I run updates on a .pdf file through FTP on a schedule to the location where it is stored in the course files under the moodledata directory. It is used for dissemination of schedules. We noticed that after the schedule was updated, the browser would not present the most up-to-date file. Instead the file which was stored in the cache was displayed. Needless to say, this created problems. Our solution was to place the file in a location accessible through a direct URL address ( http://domain.com/data/file.pdf ). After making the change, the user will now always see the latest file posted via FTP.

ResponsesInList.Title: How do you control size of resource window when it launches in new window?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Unfortunately, I am using moodle version 1.5.2, so that may have a bearing on the answer (if there is one).

When a user clicks on a resource link, I have set the resource to launch in a New Window and, according to the instructions, left the fields blank. I had set the windows to open 800x600 but that was cumbersome. Leaving the size fields blank is supposed to open the new window the same size as the window it was launched from.

Here's the (edited) instructions from the moodle:

1. Determine the size window you wish to open.

If you leave these fields blank then the new popup window will be exactly the same size as the window they clicked on to get the popup.

When I set the size to 800x600, the new window always launched as an 800x600 window. However, when the I leave the fields blank, the following happens:

If the browser is IE , then the new window opens to the correct width(!) but the height is very, very small... The new window looks like a ribbon.

If the browser is FireFox , then the new window opens correctly!

In my opinion, this behavior should be the exact opposite: works perfectly in IE, but kludgy in FireFox. If that were the case, the prerequiste for the course would be: Must use an IE browser... Unfortunately, this is not the case...

So, anyone seen this behavior? Any suggestions? Is there a workaround (besides upgrading to a more current version of moodle)?

Thanks for your help...

madea

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory: Files vs. Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Not sure if I should start a new topic on this one, but I'm hoping you're subscribed, Chardelle, and can tell me where the option to build the directory is located.  I may just be thick in the head, but I've looked all over the place.  Some of my instructors are really asking for this sort of thing (I think, since I can't quite get it to work).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory: Files vs. Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Amy, you build a directory by uploading a zipped folder of files, then unzipping it. You can also build a directory from files on your moodle site, by checking their boxes in the file viewer and choosing 'create zip archive' from the pull down. Then you can click this new zip file and download it. Whereupon you could also upload it to a new course, unzip it, and build another directory. It would be nice if the moodle upload form let you upload multiple files (the way Gallery's does for instance) at one time without zipping them, wouldn't it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory: Files vs. Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much, Michael.  Yeah, that multiple upload would rock my world, and really pump up some of the profs I'm trying to keep happy here.  At any rate, however, they're absolutely cranked about the quality and accessibility of Moodle.  Cheers!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory: Files vs. Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: The way I read your question is that you want to display a directory, not upload multiple files. To do that, turn editing on, select add resource and then choose DIRECTORY as your resource type. S

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory: Files vs. Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Amy, The Directory I was referring to is the added resource that Sarah mentioned.  It's a nice way to combine several documents into one link to try to "clean up" the course homepage.  I wanted to mention that you might like to keep an eye on the development of the new Data Management System: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?f=352 When this comes it will be the solution to so many things... Chardelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Upload Multiple files
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I am using the moodle 2.1. How can i upload multiple files in 2.1? i saw an instruction for this on moodle 1.9, but i cannot find any information related to this. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upload Multiple files
ResponsesInList.Text: Do you mean uploading multiple files by compressing/zipping them? If so, then you do this  via add a resource>folder and then clicking "add" and uploading your zipped folder. When it is uploaded it will have a little icon to the right of it - hover your cursor over it and it will offer various options, one of which is "unzip" . If you mean upload multiple files in a different way from compressing/zipping then you might be interested in doing a search for  the drag/drop file upload module which has recently been releaseed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL you are trying to add as a result of scripting (script inserts/updates rows in tables in the Moodle database)?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am building an app that inserts/updates rows in some of the tables in the Moodle database . The tables are mdl_course_sections, mdl_course_modules, mdl_context and mdl_url. Yes, as you may have guessed, I am trying to script the action of adding a URL to a section minus writing to the logs. After inserting/updating rows to add a URL, correctly (I believe), I could not see the URL, immediately, after doing a browser refresh of the course page. I realized after doing a purge of the whole Moodle website ("Site administration" -> "Development" -> "Purge all caches"), I could see the URL that I intended to add. Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL that you intended to add by scripting? (You do not have to purge the cache after manually adding the URL to see the URL.) Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL you are trying to add as a result of scripting (script inserts/updates rows in tables in the Moodle database)?
ResponsesInList.Text: No, you should not have to purge all the caches manually. Of course, your script cannot just shove data into the database and expect the Moodle caches to magically know which ones need to be cleared. Your script needs to clear the relevant cache. That probably means calling rebuild_course_cache($courseid, true);

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL you are trying to add as a result of scripting (script inserts/updates rows in tables in the Moodle database)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Tim. Exactly the answer that I was looking for. You have been ever so helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do you have to purge the cache every time you want to view the URL you are trying to add as a result of scripting (script inserts/updates rows in tables in the Moodle database)?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to purge caches during development you can do it slightly more quickly than via the web page by running purge_caches.php from moodle\admin\cli

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Basic question: text page vs. web page
ResponsesInList.Text: Margaret: Interesting question. I just chose web page because I wanted the pages to look as nice as possible (images, font styles, colours, sizes, layout of areas within the page, etc.) and I presumed I would be able to do lot more with web pages than with plain text pages. I have a web design background and I am comfortable editing the source HTML directly if required. I am a relative beginner to Moodle, so my inclination was to jump straight into web pages. As to why I didn't upload files: I wanted students to have a click-through experience. For example, the course is designed in such as way as each page continues the "narrative" -- the links then lead to other web pages, with text such as "let's learn more" or "let's find out how that works", etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: An idea for the URL resource icon in Moodle reflects the link resourced
ResponsesInList.Text: Many are discovering the advantages of using Google Drive/MS One Drive (other) for document storage and serving (including videos and audios).  In Moodle, one uses a URL resource and the icon stays the same for all such resources in a course.   The only way to indicate the URL is on Google Drive/One Drive or other is to use some designator in the link to the resource ... like a '(GD)' for a Google Drive resource. So ... a proposal ... * An alternate set of URL resource icons for: Google Drive/Docs, MS One Drive, other. * A system wide setting to use alt URL icons ... with pre-selects for Google Drive and/or Microsoft's One Drive, etc. * A setting in a course to use alt URL icons and which set. * When creating a URL resource to such a document/file, option to choose which icon. 'spirit of sharing', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: An idea for the URL resource icon in Moodle reflects the link resourced
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a good idea in principle. I don't see any need for a new setting. Different icons are just better. It would be a setting you never want to turn off, and unnecessary settings are just bad usability . If possible, the icons should be configurable, and managed using the same screen where you manage the other file type icons. The only difficulty I see is that for other file types, the icons are controlled just by the file extension. Here you would need to look at more of the URL. I don't know if the current API extends naturally to handle that, I have not looked. Note that the current API does use the file extension to determine the icon. For example if you like to http://example.com/file.pdf you get a pdf icon. This is good. I think that even after your change, if you like to https://drive.google.com/file.pdf , it should be a PDF icon. It should only be a Google doc, or Google spreadsheet icon, if you are linking to one of those. Thanks for working on this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Linking resources between courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, everybody! I'm trying to solve this problem: in my Faculty we have many reference materials that each Teacher puts in his/her own Course directory. Now: what if I would like to link one topic of my course to this material? I tried to login as administrator, as Course Creator etc, but no way: the only solution is to upload the (same) resource in my own directory/course. But what if my web/ server space wouldn't be unlimited? Briefly: I would like someone to tell me how I could link a resource (such as pdf, doc, html etc) that is not in my own course. Thank you very much!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking resources between courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately there is at the moment no single user-friendly solution for sharing resources (not just files) across courses in Moodle. Read MDL-9134 and then vote for it! If the sharing can be planned in advance (e.g., all the courses in the math department will share) then you can use a metacourse for the shared resources. However if you want sharing to be spontaneous (e.g., a teacher in a math course decides to use a file in a colleague's science course), then the shared file must exist in a publicly-accessible place on the Web. I use Site Files for shared files. Unfortunately, teachers do not typically have write access to Site Files. Most people use copy as an alternative to sharing. But copying is not sharing. Not only do you use more space, but as soon as you make a copy, you have two versions to maintain.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking resources between courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Basically all this will be resolved by the Repository API in Moodle 2.0. I really don't want to hack this into Moodle because it leads to all kinds of other problems. The idea for the future is that we use a separate repository for all user files (the respository can be all kinds of things from Internet hard drives to specialised document repository software) which Moodle accesses via a plugin to give a nice consistent interface. This is the first priority after the Bugathon. In the meantime, even now you can store files externally somewhere and reference them in resources using their URL . It's just more manual and less secure than the repository API will be.

If this construction is pasted in as source rather than in WYSIWIG mode, the

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: and to make matters worse
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David I have done a little tinkering with Moodle and SVG. SVG is a good way to introduce XML , as well as vector graphic concepts, to students. However, I have encountered similar inconsistent behaviour with browsers. Even the FireFox SVG1.1 native support is incomplete. https://developer.mozilla.org/en/svg_in_firefox In general, I have found recent versions of Opera to have the best native SVG support, closely followed by Chrome & Safari. See also this useful summary: http://www.codedread.com/svg-support.php Incidentally, Opera now host an excellent Web Standards Curriculum that includes some useful articles on SVG . I usually just add .svg files as resources (I don't try to embed them in, say, course pages). Students can similarly attach them to forum posts or submit as assignment files. It may be worth checking you have the SVG mime-type in your Moodle's /lib/fileslib.php. There should be the following entry: 'svg' => array ('type'=>'image/svg+xml', 'icon'=>'image.gif'), It *should* be there anyway, but just in case! Similarly, it may be worth confirming your Webserver is serving up the correct SVG mime-type, particularly if you are hosting .svg files outside Moodle. It *may* also be worth trying the Google Chrome Frame plugin or SVG Web for Internet Explorer or rather than the 'no-longer-supported' Adobe SVG plugin. That said, I have not actually tried these and, in the case of SVG Web, it does seem rather daft to have to use Flash to render SVG! http://googlecode.blogspot.com/2009/10/svg-at-google-and-in-internet-explorer.html http://code.google.com/p/svgweb/ http://www.adobe.com/svg/viewer/install/ Roll-on HTML5 and IE9 !! Was also going to recommend http://wiki.svg.org as an invaluable source of practical SVG information but the link is currently dead. Not sure if this is temporary or permanent.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: and to make matters worse
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Geoffrey, I had forgotten about the Opera curriculum, but yes, it is good and I might be able to use some of it! Alas, the browser inconsistencies I'm observing in this case are unique to Moodle, since the content renders properly outside Moodle. It looks as though <embed> rather than <object> allows in-line display of pre-built objects in Moodle (with scripting enabled to boot!) in IE/Opera/Chrome/Safari/FF. I think I'll have IE students use the ASV plugin until IE9 (with native SVG support) ships (the Beta will be out next month). With FF4beta now supporting SMIL (quite well), both Opera and FF are now competitive with IE/ASV in both breadth of support and speed. Webkit is fast but a bit spotty in its support. Being new to Moodle, I'm still feeling my way, but I had hoped for students to be able to draft source code directly within a Moodle resource editor without having to use a separate authoring system. I get the sense though that that would require a redefinition of what Moodle means by "resource" so that it is language neutral and not based in HTML. Wiki.svg.org was largely replaced by http://www.planetsvg.com/ though even it seems to have had little new activity this year. I'll convey your tip about mime-type configuration to our systems admin folks, though the fact that it is being served at all makes me think we've got that right. Would be happy to take this offline too. cheers david dot dailey of sru dot edu

ResponsesInList.Title: Add link to file: Keep navigation behavior is going to change
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, following http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-20320 issue, the behaviors of "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" are going to be changed: - The "Keep page navigation visible on the same page" option will concern any file type. (at this moment it works as explained into the Moodledocs : http://docs.moodle.org/en/File_or_website_link#Keep_page_navigation_visible_on_the_same_page ) - if you choose "No menu" or "Frame menu", the resource will be managed by the user browser. For example on a Mac, MP3 files will be played by Quicktime with these options. - if you choose "Menu without frame", the resource will be displayed into an object tag. The tag is created following the file extension. For example, MP3 will be played by the Moodle flash player with this option. Please test the patch and let us know your opinion, Thanks, Jerome Related post: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=132906#p582930

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to file: Keep navigation behavior is going to change

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Import Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are an editing teacher in a course, you will see the Import function under Administration on the left side menu.  To import activities and resources from other courses you must be an editing teacher in the courses you want to import from.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Import Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Mike It is in the Administration menu or Administration block, as it is known, where you have the function to import. It depends on your role whether you see that function or not. If you are the (editing) teacher of the course you should normally see it. ResponsesInList.Title: Speed of uploading and running Powerpoints
ResponsesInList.Text: We are finding that Uploading a large Powerpoint (1.94mb) times out with a php error referring to a 30 second limit. A 600kb Powerpoint takes some time to upload but then, when used as a resource, it takes a long time to run. If we short circuit the procedure and load the ppt to the Moodle server using MyComputer and hyperlinking it from a document in Moodle then this gives no problem and is very fast. We even tried a 16mb file this way and were impressed by the speed. This seems to indicate that there is something in the coding of Moodle that is slowing the process or it could be our settings for Moodle? Has anybody come across this before and is there a remedy? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Speed of uploading and running Powerpoints
ResponsesInList.Text: Uploading through web browser is always much slower than through FTP . The time out is due to your PHP settings (max_execution_time in the php.ini), nothing to do with Moodle. You can set max_execution_time greater than 30 seconds, or have your sysadmin do it. If you are getting this trying to upload a 1.6MB file, it indicates that your server is probably pretty underpowered or is being overloaded. Are you running the server yourself or are you using a hosting company?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Speed of uploading and running Powerpoints
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your prompt reply. We run Moodle on its own dedicated server on our own W2003 network which, when we short cut the process by putting the Powerpoint directly on it without going through Moodle and then preparing a text page in a Moodle course with a hyperlink to it, works blisteringly fast. This must mean that the server is fine but something in either the coding of Moodle or our settings is slowing up firstly the loading and then the running of Powerpoints. Any further thoughts? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Links to online bibliographic databases
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi How are people handling links to fulltext articles in subscription based bibliographic databases or ejournals? We use ezproxy to enable off-campus users to use IP based authentication for these databases, but we have to instruct teaching staff to add the ezproxy prefix to all the URLs they create for articles in ProQuest, Ebsco etc Is anyone else dealing with this issue or use an alternative method to allow direct linking to online articles? Cheers David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Links to online bibliographic databases
ResponsesInList.Text: On EBSCO databases, it is possible to make the permanent article/journal/search URLs automatically embed your EZ Proxy information. This means the student can click an article link from home, and provided they have logged into Moodle, the link will automatically authenticate with the EZ Proxy and take them to that article. Here is the link on the EBSCO support page: http://support.epnet.com/knowledge_base/detail.php?id=1376

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Jmol resource and filter in Moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joe I have sometimes had similar symptoms, and not entirely got to the bottom of things. Seems to be a particular issue with Java 1.6 which is more 'secure' than earlier versions and grumbles about writing/overwriting files in the applet cache. Possible solutions are: refreshing the page clearing browser cache from the Java Console (Java icon bottom right on Windows) set the cache size as 0 downgrading to Java 1.5 I have also had similar symptoms, on machines where my user area quota had reached its limit, so there was no room to download the applet!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Jmol resource and filter in Moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: ...got timed out whilst editing this reply the third bullet should say... from the Java Control Panel (Java icon bottom right on Windows) set the temporary file size as 0 (counterintuitive? but seems to get rid of the security error). I also *think* it happens if you have just upgraded Jmol or are viewing pages with different versions of the Jmol applet e.g. if you have different versions of Jmol in the filter and resource. I tend to keep both updated with the latest stable Jmol applet (currently 11.4.2). Any Java gurus out there may be able to give more precise explanations/fixes. I am very aware that this impacts the usability of the Jmol resource and filter. As part of a general review and update, I'm considering the workaround, used on the http://jmol.sf.net homepage, of initially displaying an image (.jpg) rather the interactive applet. The applet would then be rendered when the user selected the image. This should speed up the loading/display of Moodle pages containing (multiple) Jmols, and also give some meaningful visual content to those without Java. Displaying the applets one-at-a-time should also be better for performance on 'legacy' client hardware. Due to other commitments, this probably won't happen for a month or two - but I'm on the case! Hope this helps

Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: pdf / images / document size questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rene, When you ask for PDF files that are displayed (like an image, I suppose), have you tried adding them as a resource (link to a file) and them setting them to be displayed in the same page? That way, when you click on its name, whatever is on the PDF will be displayed on the screen. You can also try doing a print screen of the PDF, save it as an image and then show it on the course page, but that might bring about other problems, since an image doesn't allow for the same things as a PDF (like searching text, copying, editing, etc.). When you choose to add an image you must either select it from the folder you uploaded it to, or browse your files, select the image, upload it to Moodle and then select it. The URL field indicates the place, in Moodle, where the image was saved. Alternate text is the like a tooltip. It's the text that appears when you go over the image with the mouse. The size of a file isn't measured by its number of pages, but by the space it occupies in the computer. You can add it as a resource (link to file) so that the student can download it. Anyway, if it is a Glossary, why not use Moodle's glossary activity instead? You can import the list of terms from a XML file. Resources can be downloaded, as well as displayed on the course page. That is the case for linked files, and any other files that might be saved in displayed folders, for instance. Hope it helped!

ResponsesInList.Title: How do I get all my flash output files to work together?
ResponsesInList.Text: I hope this question is not too shallow.  I have tried to research it but fall short of finding an answer. I am using Camtasia to produce a Flash (.swf) file named Intro.  It produces these files: Intro.html; Intro.swf; Intro_config. xml ; Intro_controller.swf; Intro_nofp_bg.gif; Intro_preload.swf; mult_choice2.swf; summary_page2 I have been successful in loading to the server Intro.swf and having it play from within Moodle.  However, it does not have the Flash window controls and all the other add-ins like the quiz and preloader files. How do I combine or upload all these to make it play like I built it? Thanks in advance...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I get all my flash output files to work together?
ResponsesInList.Text: The question was apparently too shallow as seen by the lack of any response.  However, I did not give up trying and I figured it out. In case anyone else has this problem, here is what I did. I uploaded all the created Camtasia files to the server via my ftp to its intended folder destination within Moodle (uploads folder) (***this avoids the uploading size restriction issue within Moodle and PHP***). I then added a resource "Link to a file/website."  Next, I entered the html file that was created by Camtasia and it worked.  I guess the Camtasia folks wanted to make it easy.  I did not realize that the html file contained all the pointers to the other files and that they would retain their correct relationships once they were moved around from location to location. (i.e my computer to the server) Anyway, I am not a programmer type - but more a plug-in-play capable person.  So far Moodle has been great! I hope this is helpful to someone else if they encounter the same questions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Final plea: Text vanishes when composing web page
ResponsesInList.Text: This sounds like possibly a problem with the HTML Editor, perhaps due to a firewall blocking it and you might want to repost to the HTML Editor forum. Alternatively it might have something to do with the character encoding in your Moodle database .  See the following discussion: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=22644

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Final plea: Text vanishes when composing web page
ResponsesInList.Text: Diane, Why not try the Teacher Play Area on Moodle.org? I suppose the reason you are not getting a response is that the problem has so many variables.  I know for my site (and localhost versions) the HTML editor has been pretty consistent from 1.4.4 to the present 1.5+, though it does regularly clean out certain (predictable) chunks of code when editing or saving.  One also gets surprising results from missing or mistyped tags.  But I am guessing you are describing a more general problem that may be difficult for others to reproduce.  I would suggest checking the HTML editor forum discussions -- there may be something in there that relates to your problem. Good luck, Jim.

ResponsesInList.Title: PDF Download Issue in Android Browser
ResponsesInList.Text: I am setting up a Moodle Site and most (if not all) of our users will be using an Android Phone. For the most part, Moodle has worked great on a mobile phone (using HTC Incredible). I've only made a few changes to the default theme, and in general, Moodle looks great as long as the phone is in Lanscape Mode. The last thing I plan to do is use browser detection and increase the font size in a few places (load alternate CSS ). So far, the only issue that I can't seem to work around deals with PDF downloads. Here are the scenarios - all using the Resource Module "Link to a file or website" : 1) Force Download CHECKED - After the link is tapped, the user is prompted with the message "The content is not support on the phone. No application can be found to open this file. Do you still want to download it?" The next options are to "Download" or "Exit". If you click download, the file downloads, but when you try to open the file, the file does not open. You can browse to the file using the PDF Reader and then open. 2) Force Download UNCHECKED - Browser loads loads and appears to redirect to the URL of the file but then just returns to the page it is on. The file does not open or download. 3) External Link to PDF (hosted on the same server , domain , etc.) - It works perfectly! The file downloads automatically and the user is prompted to open in the default application or if there are multiple PDF apps, then the user can pick which app to use. I would prefer for the course creator to be able to use the built-in upload /file manager and all that the resource module has to offer. Since it doesn't appear to be a server issue, it seems that the code could be edited to fix this problem. Does anyone have any suggestions? P.S, I also have this same issue with the Certificate Module, downloading the generated PDF certificate. This module doesn't generate a link but instead, a form button that the user clicks on. There are no settings - so I haven't been able to try anything else with it, but I plan on making a post in its forum.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PDF Download Issue in Android Browser
ResponsesInList.Text: I am curious - did you ever find a solution to this?  I am having the same issue with Android Phones.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PDF Download Issue in Android Browser
ResponsesInList.Text: We had a similar problem here with Moodle 2.1. Any PDF files displayed in a "File" resource in the default setting ("Display: Automatic") were not being displayed on mobile devices, or only in an embedded PDF viewer that did not allow to scroll to the next page of the PDF. A workaround is to use the "Display: Open" setting instead. See also MDL-29987 .

ResponsesInList.Title: login page comes when trying to create uploaded file resource
ResponsesInList.Text: On one machine here the teacher is thrown to the login page when trying to create a resource of type uploaded file. Everything proceeds as usual, including the uploading and choosing of the file. But then when the teacher clicks on "Save changes"  he is asked to log in again. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: login page comes when trying to create uploaded file resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Gustav, I experienced this with earlier versions of Moodle 1.2x off and on while it was in beta (IE6+XP).  A few days ago while exploring build 2004042703 of version 1.3, that's all I experienced.  After a few hours of trying to determine what "might" be going on, I concluded that the HTML editor was probably the culprit.  In my case, a course uploaded that had a different moodledata storage path would 100% of the time cause the bounce to login screen problem, as soon as the HTML editor was fired up.  I suppose it was only doing what it thought it was supposed to be doing, as a file browser . It other words, if it was asked to load into its file manager window resources located somewhere in non-public storage, it would attempt to login to that Moodle site (hence the login screen).  In fact, I suspect that if you have any files/resources used in Moodle A, and stored in Moodle B, this problem may occur. The good news is that build 2004043001 (April 30th and later) seems to have fixed the problem.  Try as I might, I cannot get things to go south when I fire up the HTML editor, even with resources at another location.  The file manager simply displays an error message in the view pane on right, and then nicely lets you select a local Moodle resourse in the left view pane without sending you to the login screen.  A fairly stable build I'm finding, so far. As an aside, if your teacher has more than one cookie for the same Moodle site in their cache, this might also be a problem.  Have them flush browser cache while not logged in, and see if problem still persists.

ResponsesInList.Title: Confirm a document has been read?
ResponsesInList.Text: I ned to have a lsit of policy documents and have each user confirm that they have been read. Something like a Site Policy. Any one know of an easy way to achieve this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Confirm a document has been read?
ResponsesInList.Text: May I suggest you use a Lesson ? You can make each page in the Lesson a policy document, or part of a document. End each page with a question that has three answers, like: Choose one of the following: 1. I have read the document and want to continue to the next document [score 1 and jump to next page] 2. I have read the document and want to exit [score 1 and exit] 3. I have not read the document and want to exit [score 0 and exit] If the policy documents are long, break them up into multiple lessons. Make a page for each section. The end of lesson page can have a "congratulations you've finished this document" message and a link to download the pdf version of the document. And by default, when a student re-enters a Lesson, (s)he sees the last page or branch table that (s)he viewed. That's a nice feature to ensure continuity for your readers. You can also use the Certificate module to send an email to someone when the student completes the lesson (reads the entire document). See the discussion here http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=95672 . You can set up the Certificate module so that the student gets the certificate only after scoring 100% (reading all the sections ). See the "Lesson dependency trick" here http://docs.moodle.org/en/Certificate_module#Lesson_dependency_trick_1 . At this point you might be wondering, "How does displaying a certificate equal sending an email?" The answer is that you can set the Certificate module to email the certificate, to the student and the teacher. It's a workaround to get Moodle to send an email upon completion of a Lesson, but it gets the job done. Hope this helps. I'd be interested to hear the solution you finally go with.

ResponsesInList.Title: 1.8 Resource-Forced Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: I can't find any way to disable this in the Resource settings or the roles system, unless I'm just not finding this setting, it seems like a bug in 1.8 as this isn't mentioned as an intentional feature in the 1.8 release notes. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Category:Moodle_1.8 http://docs.moodle.org/en/Release_Notes#Moodle_1.8 Why folks might not want this as a feature: If you do a good job of writing a summary, it can take a good deal of time, and faculty like to do a good job on their courses. Many faculty feel that good summaries will act like "Cliff notes" the students will read the summaries and not read the full articles. It also is a big human resource hit for large sites-if you have 1000 faculty each now spending an extra 3 minutes per resource writing decent summaries, your total cost to run Moodle has just shot through the roof. Suggested solutions: There should be a way to turn this off in the Admin module config along with all the other settings that can be set for resources. Or even nicer, a new resource capability:imakeyousummarize, so that a single site could have some courses where summaries are forced and others where they are not. Anyway, think this is a bug as described above, so I've put it in the tracker as: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-9485

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: admin roles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sundeep If I understand both of these questions correctly you need to have a good look at Roles . The Admin can assign a user (teacher) as a Course Creator which provides that user with the ability to create a course and teach in it. The Admin can also assign users as teachers in a course then remove their access when not required (or provide them with a different role that is not as high as a teacher). ResponsesInList.Title: How to Make an Illustrated Lecture
ResponsesInList.Text: I just spent the afternoon playing around trying to create something that I will need for my courses, and that is a way to display illustrated lectures. I wanted a simple way to use the html editor within the resource module to create pages that otherwise look like plain text resources but with a column of images on the left side (which would display a "caption" on mouseover) and text on the right. I wanted the image column to stay a constant width, whereas I wanted the text to be able to be resized if the user resized his browser. Bryan Williams suggested to someone that they might use tables to reduce the width of text in the generaltextbox and this inspired me to use tables to create the effect I wanted as well. I have now created a "template" that simply requires entering the lecture text, the image paths and caption text into the html template. This could even be used offline and then the resulting html simply needs to be pasted into the editor. I have been doing all this with the test moodle account at opensourcecms.com since I don't have my own Moodle set up yet, so I can't show you an example of what it looks like, but I've attached the html with the usage instructions embedded if anyone is interested in playing around with it.

ResponsesInList.Title: MP3 file resources, player does not show
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Since our upgrade to Moodle 3.10.8, we have noticed that there is something awry with file resource that have an MP3 file. Normally, when opening such a resource a page opens with a player on it, but lately the player is gone. Something is stopping the multimedia filters (Poodle and the regular multimedia filter) from working. MP3 flies that have been added to text editors and linked to do generate a player. I wonder if anyone else has (had) this same problem and if they have any suggestions as to how to solve it. Kind regards, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MP3 file resources, player does not show
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I have now been able to narrow this issue down to specifically the File resource page when it opens automatically. When set to Open or to Pop up, the MP3 file plays. I discovered that this issue has to do with the Poodll filter, for when the Multimedia filter is raised above the Poodll filter in the Manage filters list, the problem goes away. I request that the moderator transfers this thread to the Poodll forum, so as to avoid double posting. Thanks, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Updating Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I tweak my moodle resource files (generally word documents) quite often. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Interesting question. I suppose a good answer depends.. I don't know that MS has built ftp capabilities into their software, but you could essentially do the same thing instead of uploading by using a link for your resources to a file at say google shared documents. With this, you've work in your browser, log into your google account, edit as you wanted. This could even be a collaborative document. Then I wonder what's the big hassle about your ' upload ' process. Perhaps if you used something like Dreamweaver, which produces good html and also manages websites, in one click, your MSword document revision would be 'uploaded'. And, if you were willing to go with a simpler text editor rather than requiring all the formatting of the bloatware Word, you could probably use something like BBEdit (Mac) and open and edit your document on the server . Care, and probably not too helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Post Resources, but Nothing Else??

Is this possible without having the resources and forums in separate courses?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Post Resources, but Nothing Else??

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Post Resources, but Nothing Else??
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steve, use groups, put your secretary in one group, she can post to an open forum. Put everyone else in another group, set the forums you want to post to to use separate groups. Now she could still post to these forums, but she won't be able to see your posts/dicussions. This isn't ideal, one thing we're working on is a block that should make controlled file sharing easier (see block_shared_files in CVS ).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Failed to write file to disk Error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, have you checked the free space amount on the disk where your files should be saved? Ivana

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Failed to write file to disk Error
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know where the files get saved. Can you help me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Failed to write file to disk Error
ResponsesInList.Text: It's hard to say anything without more info. I suppose your Moodle is not installed and hosted on your own computer? Would it be possible to ask your Moodle administrator, he could check that for you - he needs to login to the server where Moodle is. If you are "just" a regular user, without access to the server where Moodle is, you will not be able to check it yourself anyway.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Failed to write file to disk Error
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Failed to write file to disk Error
ResponsesInList.Text: I know this dredges up an old post but I had this error and thought I should post the solution I figured out.  In my case the issue was that PHP was having problems writing a file to the temp directory and "Failed to write file to disk Error" was the result.  This happend only for files larger than 1MB, even though all max upload file sizes were set to 100MB.  My solution was to edit the php.ini file and make sure to set the upload_tmp_dir setting, make sure that folder existed and that write permissions were enabled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: I know of two cases of external programs being used as "program" resources: webwork and brainstorm. Are there any more? The original code for this was contributed, and I never had much time to look at it. I was just documenting it though, and I feel like I want to clean it up somewhat, including changing some variable names. This would break any current use of the program resource, but will hopefully make it easier to use in future applications. My proposed list of the information to be sent to external applications is: moodle_navigation: current crumb trail as a serialized, encoded array moodle_resource: the resource id moodle_username: current username

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Could you please include the "ID Number" in the variables to be passed? For courses where the instructor is tracking students by their student IDs, this would be invaluable. For example, I might want to have the outside resource write performance data to a separate (non-Moodle) database .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Absolutely, yes. Good idea.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you considering to mkae Moodle "aware" of the activities in these "program resources"? For example if it is a single-student-activity-module, it would be nice if some sort of information exchange about the activity could take place. (The SCORM subset of the old AICC-standard...) If I create a kind of resource with a built-in test, I would like to communicateback to Moodle that student with id=x did the test at time=y and got the score=z.. Moodle should show these results in the Moodle student overview. (I am NOT asking for a complete CBT-structure: there are programs enough that can handle that, but their is no time and money enough in normal education institutes to develop complete tuned CBTs..) With Moodle you arrange activities in a more loose way, so should be the student-result-overview ..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, this is the bidirectionality I mentioned briefly. Mostly it would be returning grades.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, Actually we had to hack the program resource code in v. 1.0.8.1 a bit to get it to work with WeBWorK. We're now rewriting the interface as a separate module, instead of interfacing with the program resource code. So I guess it really doesn't matter for us how you rewrite this code. However just a few comments on your proposed list of information to be passed to an external program.  In my interface with WeBWorK, it is much more convenient to use a single password to the interface, instead of distinct passwords for every URL which accesses the interface, as you are proposing. I don't want to have course creators to have to enter this password every time they create such a URL.  Indeed for the sake of security, I don't want them to know this password. I think you should allow this alternative means of setting up a password. Also I pass the current time (at which the URL was invoked) and hash it with the other information, to guard against replay attacks into WeBWorK. Zig

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, good idea about the password. It should at least be an option.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Zig! It's a year later, but we're actually re-implementing the Program resource module right now, it will make it easy to insert nearly any field from the user, course and config tables, plus a few other things. In addition you can pass these to any Moodle file as well outside URLs. I'm interested in making this as secure as possible, though. What else can we add? You mentioned hashing the time with other information to guard against replay attacks ... can you please explain this in more detail? How does it help? If anyone else has any good ideas for encrypted methods for making a program link more secure, please come forth!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Zig, very helpful! I like the idea of using the client IP in particular, since that's something that can be easily determined at both ends without sending any data like the time over in the clear. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Program resources
ResponsesInList.Text: The new "program resources" are working well in development CVS now. The changes are significant, and old-style program resources are not upgraded to the new system, so please redo your old program resources if you had any. The way it works now is as extra parameters on the standard resource type for adding a file (both uploaded files and external URLs).  There is a big list of data to choose from (suggestions for more are welcome!), and you can assign it any parameter name you like. I expect to see this used a lot to pass information to Javascript and Flash files within Moodle, as well as external web sites. Here is a simple example that may give you some idea of what is now possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Resource sharing error.
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't upload a file to course A and then use it in course B, because the files uploaded to course A are only accessible to users of that course. If you are the admin of your site, though, you can upload the file to the site's "Files" and then make it available in both courses, A and B.

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I move multiple files from one topic/week to another?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to do this? moving them one by one is quite cumbersome. Any insight is greatly appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I move multiple files from one topic/week to another?
ResponsesInList.Text: I just stumbled upon the same problem, and even if the question is old and probably you found another solution or gave up, here is a way that I found to do it: 1) create a new topic / week, 2) move the new topic/week close to the topic/week where you have the objects you want to block-move, 3) move the objects to the new created topic, here you have to do it one by one, but since the topics are contiguous it is not so much work, especially if you have " ajax " enabled, 4) move the new created topic with the objects you already moved close the topic week were you want to put them, 5) proceed manually again to move them there. Of course this solution works best with "ajax" enabled, moving them with the arrows is a pain.

ResponsesInList.Title: Updating a pdf file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I am a new Moodle user organizing by Topics.  The Resources I have added to most Topics are folders each of which contains a set of PDF files.  For example, in the Chapter 4 Topic, I have a folder called Notes containing files named Section_4.1.pdf, Section_4.2.pdf, etc.  I made some changes to my original Word file for Section 4.1, saved the changes to my computer in pdf format, and tried to upload to Moodle still naming the revised file Section_4.1.pdf.  However, Moodle reverts to the original Section_4.1.pdf. How can I update a pdf file and still use the old Moodle name? Thank you for any help you can offer. Dotty  Delaware County Community College

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating a pdf file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have seen this behaviour some times. In every case, it was due to caching, either brwoser caching proxy or server caching.  You are seeing the old page stored in memory (or disk), not the new one. This occurs if both files are named the same. If you "refresh" (or "reload", or press F3, the name varies among browsers) the page in the browser then the brwoser will be forced to actually reload again the data, and you will see the correct file. - Enrique -

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating a pdf file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Enrique, Your suggestion worked perfectly.  Thank you for taking the time to help me. Dotty

ResponsesInList.Title: Import text format problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: I recently developed a method of converting courses to Moodle 1.8 from Blackboard 6.3. A problem that i'm having, is that the summary is generated from the first 100 characters of the resource body. This means that if the resource body had some content that starts out like this: "Here is some content. I hope that someone can help me solve this problem because I am having some difficulty with it. Moodle Forums are very active and helpful." Then the summary would look like this: "Here if some content. I hope that someone can help me solve this problem because I am having some diff" You can see that the most undesirable thing is that the summaries end up being chopped off in the middle of words/sentences. I thought of a few possible solutions: 1: Delete the summary from the resources page or force it to be blank. 2: Extend the length of the summary from 100 chars to something larger. 3: Make the summary by reading until the first end of sentence character (period, exclamation, or question mark).

ResponsesInList.Title: IE7 format problem
ResponsesInList.Text: I've been using Firefox for some time but find it freezing when I save after creating a longish web page so I have starting using IE & have no freezing. However with the new IE7 the web page comes out in a narrow vertical block rather than across the page. Strangely, 'Assignments' format OK, across the page normally. Is there any fix for this? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: IE7 format problem
ResponsesInList.Text: After playing around with this, if I select the text & use 'preformatted' & save, the text works as before, across the page. It's when it's on 'normal' that the problem occurs, the text appears in a long vertical box. Unfortunately the preformatted isn't as interesting as the normal. All is fine in Firefox. (Also noticed that the top right image is missing with the 'camoodle' theme in IE7 - in the banner across the top. Was fine with IE6, as was the above problem.) I was wondering if any setting in IE7 could be changed to help this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Enable resource on specific time range (hours/minutes)
ResponsesInList.Text: when adding resource I have option to limit the dates in which it will be available, is there an option to also limit by hours/minutes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Instructor used carats in resource and ruined course!
ResponsesInList.Text: One instructor entitled their new Resource as follows: < insert title here > Apparently it was read as markup and for some reason ended the parsing of the page! Therefore there was nothing after that resource, including a right hand column. They had just done a backup so we restored from that, but some others may not be so lucky.

ResponsesInList.Title: uploaded file in resourses not veiwable
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Everybody, I installed Moodle 1.8 on a public shared hosting server . When I add a resourse by uploading a file, the file is not veiwable(doesn't show) when the link created is clicked. I tried all types of files i.e. 1)JPEG image 2)excel document & 3)Power point presentation. I tried Power point presentation after saving it as a web page i.e. with .htm extention. I checked the settings of Internet Explorer i.e. security settings, allowing pop-ups, active X controls etc. When the link created is clicked, Internet explorer opens in a new window(chose the option of new window in resourse settings) & shows the message http404 not found. When I click the details of error, it shows that IE was able to contact the website but required web page not found. Problem is with Moodle's data directory or something else? Link on the course page is created properly, file is uploaded properly only unable to see the file content. Anybody please help. Rgds Mahesh

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: uploaded file in resourses not veiwable
ResponsesInList.Text: The reason might be the same as in http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=71375

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: uploaded file in resourses not veiwable
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot. It solved the problem. Rgds Mahesh

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: uploaded file in resourses not veiwable
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot. It solved the problem. Rgds Mahesh

ResponsesInList.Title: Uploaded resource frame vanishes when upgrading from 1.3x to 1.4x
ResponsesInList.Text: I've just tried upgrading my test installation from moodle 1.3.4 to 1.4.2 and have discovered a major problem. All of the courses on my server use uploaded files for the content, but while upgrading to 1.4.2, I have discovered that the navigation bar is no longer displayed by when viewing such resources. This seems to be due to a new feature allowing the user to specify whether or not the nav bar is visible for individual resource, unfortuantly the default for this feature changes the previous behavour of moodle, which showed the nav bar above uploaded pages. The new feature is good and potentially useful, but it really should preserve the previous behaviour as the default. There is no way I can roll out 1.4.2 onto our main server, since this would break every single course on our server and require every single page resource in every course to be edited to get back the nav bar. There are 1000's of such resources and this would take weeks to do ! Is there any way of globally re-enabling the nav bar for uploaded resource without having to spend weeks editing every single resource ? I've looked and can't find any options.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploaded resource frame vanishes when upgrading from 1.3x to 1.4x
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm assuming since nobody has replied that there is no solution to this problem. So i'll treat it as bug and report it in the relevant place.

ResponsesInList.Title: IMS Content Package annoyances
ResponsesInList.Text: When creating a IMSCP resource I encountered the following problems: Creating the Moodle resource worked fine; however, when you re-open the settings form, the file name of the IMS CP module is no longer visible. When you are playing the IMSCP module, it always shows a Table of Contents that cannot be surpressed. AFAIK the table of contents is derived from the "organisations" element in the IMS CP manifest. AFAIK it is allowed to have zero organisation elements. Therefore, to get rid of the table of contents when playing the module, I removed the organisation element. The result is that Moodle does not play the IMS CP module at all due to a file error. Best regards
role: Picture of Pieter van der Hijden

ResponsesInList.Text: Tomasz, Just a guess - have you made the items "not available to students" when you set them up? I have sometimes made an entire block hidden and then all resources in that section are also hidden (look for a little closed eye). Jeff

ResponsesInList.Title: Updating File in Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using 1.8 and having problems updating a file being referenced in the resource module. Because you evidently can not edit referenced files directly within Moodle I have a Word document that I have updated and saved to my local folder. I went clicked on the Update icon next to the reference taking me to Edit Resource and clicked on the Choose or Upload a file button. There, I selected and deleted the file I want to update (which asked me if I wanted to delete the file completely and I answered yes). Returning to the Choose or Upload a File location, I then uploaded the new updated Word file. I then went to the Link to a File or Web site location, deleted the file, then clicked Save Changes. I then returned to Edit Resource location, selected the new updated file (it having the more recent date/time stamp). It opens the file up but I STILL HAVE THE OLD VERSION!!! What am I doing wrong? This seems very convoluted to make simple changes to a referenced file!! Thank You

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating File in Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dale, I'd recommend a couple of things you might want to try out. 1. Clear your cache file, or better yet, try to access the file on a different computer.  It might be that your browser is actually not trying to download the file. 2. When I change, I usually do this through FTP .  This way, I don't have to worry anything about the links themselves within moodle. Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Updating File in Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you giving the new file the same name as the older version? It will work if you give it a different name. It is a cache issue, yes, but for speed of success I usually just rename an updated file.

ResponsesInList.Title: set of .html files as resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I would like to know if I can configure inside moodle a set of .htmls files so it would be traceable (each individual .html file). I mean, suppose I have 1.html, 2.html and 3.html. And suppose I have a link inside 1.html that points to 2.html file. And a link inside 2.html file tha points to 3.html file. Making 1.html the main file, if I navigate (using the links) to 2.html and 3.html, the student log would show me only the 1.html visited. But I want that it tracks and show on reports also 2.html and 3.html access? The book module seems to allow me create .html files traceable but it has the drawbacks I cannot use any . css , or .js. In the book module I am restricted to .html that is wrapped by moodle. The solution it seems possible so far is to use a SCORM package. But it seems SCORM is not very flexible in termos of HTML5, CSS3 and Javascript . I can also create each .html file as a resource. But it could be very tiring to set an entire course full of hundreds of .html pages. Anyone that had the same requirements and could share a solution?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: set of .html files as resource
ResponsesInList.Text:
You CAN use CSS within the Book module. Depending on what/how much you want to target, you could use... 
```text
#page-mod-book-view {}
```
 or 
```text
.box.generalbox.book_content {}
```
 You can even target individual books, eg. 
```text
.cmid-78 {}
```
 You also reference external css and js using the 'Additional HTML’ settings in Site Admin > Appearance. Alternatively, you can upload multiple html files to the File activity. Mark your first page as the 'Set Main Page', and it will behave like a mini website within Moodle. See https://docs.moodle.org/30/en/File_resource_settings#Displaying_a_website_index_page for more info.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: set of .html files as resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the answer. We are trying to create a "mini website" as you called. It seems the book option will not work since we want do use css and js so as to create rich interfaces (something like: circular menus, accordions, lightboxes, image galleries, drag and drop interaction and animations). I will study the "Additional HTML" settings you mentioned. The File activity as you pointed is at the moment our best choise but it has a drawback that it does not track the pages individually so we could see which pages the student has visited. For instance: Making 1.html the main file, if I navigate (using the links) to 2.html and 3.html, the student log would show me only the 1.html visited. But I want that it tracks and show on reports also 2.html and 3.html access? Maybe I am doing something wrong. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: set of .html files as resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Márcio, I think you might be able to do what you want to do by using the Lesson activity with content or question pages as your html page. I do know that when a user visits/naswers a question page, it appears in the logs. Another possibility is to use a combination of page resources with various Generico filters for the menus, accordions, lightboxes, image galleries, etc. Of course, all the Generico stuff can be used in the Lesson activity, as well as in the Book resource.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Book Module - How to get a block above the Table of Contents
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 2.6 - I am trying to get an HTML block above the Table of Contents produced by the Book module. Even if I select priorty -10, it doesn't happen. Is there a nice or even hacky way to get a block to appear above the Book Table of Contents?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Book Module - How to get a block above the Table of Contents
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe this is not possible. The table of contents blocks is a fake block and is added by the book code, which means all other blocks on the activity display below it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Book Module - How to get a block above the Table of Contents
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks - so I will either build my  block into the Book block or find a way to deprioritise it. Merci!

ResponsesInList.Title: Moving files out of a repository
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I am about to migrate my moodle from 1.9.16 to 2.3.3 but there is still something that's keeping me from migrating. Up until now, once a year I move all course files (lessons, assignments, foro attachments and so on)  from my web server to a backup copy. I need to do that because I have to pay for any extra disc I use.  Besides, I want to keep the courses structure so I can keep students enrolments, grades, etc...which is quite necessary for my organization. That's why I can not delete old courses. My question is, how can I move all those files out of the repository in one go without deleting a course? Is there any moodle function that I can use? Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving files out of a repository
ResponsesInList.Text: The file structure for Moodle 2 is very different from 1.9, so it may not be possible to do what you want -- but I'm no expert. With luck, someone will be able to tell you how to do this in Moodle 2. However, what you could do is set up your own Moodle server on your personal/office computer, then backup the Moodle courses online and restore them to your local host system. Then you can delete them from the pay-for server while still having access to the marks etc when you need them. This may be using a sledge-hammer or wrecking ball to crack a nut, but the nut will be cracked. Anne

ResponsesInList.Title: can't modify an uploaded file
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a  course set up and want to make some changes. It says in the help area to just upload the file with the same name and it will automatically be overwritten. This doesn't seem to be the case however. I have uploaded the file by the same name but the old version still appears. I have deleted the file and uploaded again and still the old version appears. I have used refresh to refresh the page. To no avail. What is the problem? Thanks for any help Jacira

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: can't modify an uploaded file
ResponsesInList.Text: The old document is still cached somewhere (not necessarily in your own browser, could be anywhere between your server and your browser). The document has a lifetime of 24 hours by default but you can change that by setting $CFG->filelifetime to the number of seconds somewhere in your config.php file. The only way to make sure that the new file is available immediately is to give it a different name.

I've added a couple of lines to filelib.php: 'mobi' => array ('type'=>'application/x-mobipocket-ebook', 'icon'=>'mobi'), 'mobi' => array ('type'=>'AZW/Mobi', 'icon'=>'mobi'), (For the record, I added the second after the first didn't work, just to see...) I've added the appropriate icons to my theme's pix_core/f/ folder, where there are other icons currently overriding the defaults. I also used "Purge all caches" from the Administration > Development menu, to see if that would help. Just for kicks, I added the mimetype to my server 's .htaccess: AddType application/x-mobipocket-ebook .mobi Nothing seems to work. The problem seems to be that Moodle isn't recognizing the mimetype. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add New Mimetype in 2.6
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I've got it—here's what I learned, for future reference: (1) I probably should have tried this earlier, but clicking the "display file details" button in the uploader show the mimetype of the files you're uploading. In this case, it turns out I needed AZW/mobi. Huh. (2) Out of desperation, I threw my same mobi.png files into the core pix/f/ folder, and the mobi icons all of a sudden appeared as expected. That didn't make sense, since my epub icons in my theme's pix_core/f/ folder were overriding the original epub icons. And then it did make sense—I'm guessing that my mobi icons in my theme's folder weren't overriding Moodle's default icon because there was no default icon to override in the first place. When I added a mobi icon to the core, everything clicked into place. Main lesson ? When adding a completely new mimetype, add the icons to the core instead of the theme. (I suppose.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't worry - I've worked it out - you use "directory"!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: can you explain this a bit more? I have hundreds of files in several folders i need to upload, it would be handy if i could just upload the folders but i've no idea how to.....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Trish, Go to the module you wish to insert your folders into Click on "add a resource" Click on "display a directory" Insert what you want to call your folder Click on "save changes" You will then be offered all the resources showing in the module you wish to insert your folder into. Select the resources and follow remaining instructions Obviously, you will need to have saved all the contents of your folders as resources in the appropriate module before you can select them to put into your new folder (there is probably a much easier and faster way to do it than this, but I only had one or two folders to create so didn't need to find a faster/shorter route) Best of luck Trish Linda

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. You need to get your folder on your computer's hard drive and right click it - choose send to>compressed/zipped folder. You will get the same folder again but with a zip on. Then go to your course page on Moodle,click on files in the admin block and upload your zipped folder in the same way as you would upload a single resource. Then when you have got the folder (ending in .zip) into your course files, click to unzip it - it will list all the contents and you click OK to accept it. You'll then get the folder again, unzipped and you can either display each individual resource separately or you can do as suggested and use the 'display a directory' option in Add a Resource to show the whole folder on the page. Students then just click on the folder and can access the resources themselves. This makes the page a bit neater.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: thank you very much for this. That's given me a very quick and easy way to cope with what was threatening to be a very difficult problem!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploading folders to the resource area
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Trish, just one thing I'd recommend taking into consideration... if you manually place the folder into the module and then use the display directory function, make sure the file names have no spaces, since if they do you (nor students) will not be able to download any files.  If you use the .zip option you don't have to worry, since moodle will create the files replacing the spaces with underscores.

ResponsesInList.Title: Question Marks replacing some characters in htm files
ResponsesInList.Text: Good day, We have been experiencing problems with htm files in our migration process from another LMS to Moodle (applies only to htm files produced in Microsoft Word or PowerPoint).  Question marks are appearing instead of long dashes,  single quotes (magic quotes I believe they're called), and repeated spaces. In all the posts I've read, the question mark issue comes up for non-English characters when the default Character Set is not set to UTF-8.  I'm wondering if this is our problem as well. Our install is Moodle 1.5.3: Fedora Core 2 MySQL 3.23.58 PHP 4.3.4 mbstring enabled (OK status for all these in Moodle Environment page). In order to test if this is a UTF-8 related issue, I then installed Moodle 1.6.3 on a different machine (running CentOS 4.3). I uploaded a couple of the htm files, and the same problem occurs.  Note though, this second Moodle instance  is not yet UTF-8, since the Environment page mbstring status says Check.  The Environment page also says that the My SQL version installed needs to be upgraded in order to guarantee that all data will be converted to UTF-8 in the future. I'm still new to linux, and have been unsuccessful thus far in upgrading MySql or installing/enabling mbstring (GD also has to be installed/enabled). My question is, with respect to the question marks, can anyone say for sure that this is definitely (or definitely not) a UTF-8 related issue? We have quite alot of these htm files to clean up (a number of work-arounds have been discovered, but they involve processing each htm file, one at a time).  Our hope is that there is some setting to change which will allow all such files to display correctly. Thanks, Lindsay.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question Marks replacing some characters in htm files
ResponsesInList.Text: Good day, The problem has been resolved.  The solution actually, required a change in the settings away from UTF-8 in apache (commenting out the default character set which was set to UTF-8, and commenting out some of the mbstring settings). The Microsoft produced htm files now display correctly! Hope this helps anyone else who experienced this problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: powerpoint
ResponsesInList.Text: I couldnt' find an appropriate forum to post this thread so I am putting it on here. Does anyone know if I could put a powerpoint presentation on Moodle as a resource link?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: powerpoint
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, by all means. Upload in the usual way; choose 'add a resource' and select your powerpoint. However - it might also be worth putting a link to Powerpoint viewer in case your students don't have Powerpoint installed at home. Or else point them in the direction of Open Office Impress which will read Powerpoint.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: powerpoint
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a discussion of this in the docs, btw . One concern for me has always been the question of client apps, and for me the fewer and more open the client apps the better all are. That being said, I think you are well served by converting the ppt file to flash or converting the ppt to web. In the former case you can simply upload and link to one file (and you are requiring that all have access to a flash viewer) and in the latter you would need to zip up all the files produced and upload them to an appropriate directory and unzip, linking to the contents html doc from you resource page, in which case you need no additional clients. Of course you could always look at using something like S5 . Critical issues for me have been: Whether the format deployed can be opened with an open client (ppt can not) Whether the format deployed has helper apps on all platforms (again, nix on ppt) Whether the format deployed is easily managed (ppt ranks a so-so in my book) Having supported students using OS X, MS-Windows and a variety of linux flavors, my choice has been S5 or html first, followed by flash.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: powerpoint
ResponsesInList.Text: I think a search of Moodle Docs would be helpful: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Special:Search?search=powerpoint&go=Go

ResponsesInList.Title: Spreadsheet macros vs. security issues - how to get macros working?

Problem seems to lie in the security levels of Moodle. This cannot be altered, says the administration. Is there a by-way or am I posing a wrong question? Yours truly Juha-Pekka Rautanen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Spreadsheet macros vs. security issues - how to get macros working?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have uploaded Excel files and when they are downloaded the macros work fine. The security warnings I get are related to Microsoft Excel's security settings and nothing to do with Moodle. Moodle settings, I think, can prevent you uploading certain types of file but this doesn't sound like your problem. VBA can do some pretty nasty stuff and many network admins will not allow the security settings to be changed to allow it with good reason. We set the security to high and users have to make a deliberate decision to lower it using the tools - macro - security menu (set it to medium, save the file, close it and reopen it to allow macros to be used) Are you downloading the file, Saving and then opening through Excel. Or just opening which opens it in a web browser and gives you less access to the Excel interface?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Spreadsheet macros vs. security issues - how to get macros working?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Was there ever any follow-up on this issue? I am new to Moodle and am working in a support role in a third-level college. This morning I received a query from a member of academic staff. He has uploaded an Excel file to his course page. This Excel file contains macros. When students open the file, and have chosen to enable macros, they are asked to type in their student ID number. If they number they type in is incorrect, they receive an error message, but the file reopens and the students are again prompted to enable macros. If they enable macros the second time 'round, the worksheet open up. However, if a student attempts to launch any macros in the worksheet, Excel crashes. One workaround is to instruct students to save the Excel file before opening it. In this case, if student type in an incorrect ID number, the worksheet closes and does not reopen. Any ideas would be very welcome! Thanks, M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Spreadsheet macros vs. security issues - how to get macros working?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is a MS-problem. The use of excel for such a thing is a bad idea. You (student) must have the same excel version, as the author of the macro.. S.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Spreadsheet macros vs. security issues - how to get macros working?

I do not see anything in moodle that gets 'inside' an Excel file, or changes the permissions of Excel.
