ResponsesInList.Title: Resources within a web page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi People! Moodle V. 1.9 being used here. I'm in the process of developing a course which is broken down into four modules. From the main menu, a student is given an introductory statement to each module. Each module has been created in a 'topic box' which was created when I created the course. Under the introductory statement is a link going to a webpage created within moodle. Inside the webpage is the module course material, made up of course material, external websites, moodle quizes, moodle assignments, moodle resources. At the moment, I've had to create a Fifth topic which I've called "Course Resource Material - Do Not Touch". In this topic I've created the Moodle quizes and assignments that I have linked inside each of the four modules webpages. This looks really ugly and I need to think of a way around it, but can't think of anything! My question is this: Is there anyway I can create the moodle resources (quizes, assignments, resource) straight into my Web page (which has also been created with Moodle)? If not, is there anyway to create them somewhere else (maybe in another course?) and link them back? Or even have them hidden to the student but still accessible through the page? Any ideas would be muchly appreciated!! Thanks, Cory

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Resources within a web page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Cory, What I used to do in such cases is set the number of topics to display only the relevant topics. So if my resources were in the fifth I set the number of topics to 4. Yes, when I needed to add a resource I had to go to the course settings, set the number of topics to 5, add the resource and then change the settings again. Not very elegant but in courses which had a stable predefined structure this solution worked reasonably well. An alternative way which I started to use recently for a slightly different purpose but should work in this case too is to show the topic block only in editing mode. I add to course sites an html block in the bottom right corner. In this block I insert javascript which detects whether the page is in editing mode, and if it is not, I set the style.display of certain sections on the page to 'none' so that they are not displayed when not in editing mode which means that even I don't see them and bothered by their ugliness when I don't need to make changes in them. Now, you can get the editing mode from the body tag by // detect edit mode var arTmp=document.getElementsByTagName("body"); var theBody=arTmp[0]; var editMode=theBody.className.search(/editing/gi);

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Resources within a web page
ResponsesInList.Text: Itamar! You're a champ! Your idea of removing the Resource topic works perfectly! I thought that removing the topic would remove all the information contained within that topic - but NO! This works really well for me, as once the course has been fully set up, it will not be touched again (if it is, it will only be minor modification made). So having to show the topic again, is not a real issue. Again, thank you very much for this! Cory

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Resources within a web page
ResponsesInList.Text: The open universtity have created a new type of resource called a Resource Page. that allows you to do exactly what you are doing without any of the hassle of hidden topics. Unfortunatly "resource page" only works on Moodle installs that are running on the postgres database . I don't think there are any plans for the OU to widen the support of this unit but hopefully someone will make it MySQL compatible. There is a new feature issue on the Moodle Tracker about course sub pages http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-13908 that you can vote on.

ResponsesInList.Title: PowerPoint Slideshow
ResponsesInList.Text: Can someone please explain why a PowerPoint 2003 slideshow presentation (.pps), which correctly opens as a slideshow when double clicked on my PC....opens as a PowerPoint document when opened on the same PC, from the Moodle site running on a localhost and logged in as a user? More importantly...how can I fix it! Thanks, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PowerPoint Slideshow
ResponsesInList.Text: I can't explain it but I'd strongly advise you to try using a different format when  uploading powerpoint - so that everyone can access them easily without the need for downloading or having Powerpoint viewer etc..  have you tried ispringsolutions (google it !) It is a free program that converts Powerpoints to flash files, retaining animations.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PowerPoint Slideshow
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, I've been struggling with the same issue ever since Office 2007 was installed at our college. At one level I do agree with Mary's answer but there are very many people who have uploaded PowerPoint presentations on our Moodle and they still need for them to work the way they expect them to. I have today convinced our network team here to make the following registry change (as advised in a Microsoft technical post): Start Registry Editor Locate and click this key in the registry: HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\PowerPoint.Show.8 Double click on the Data type: REG_DWORD Change the Value data: to 8 Close Registry Editor Try this on your local PC and it should fix the problem. The bigger issue is that you can't control what's happening for all your other users. For us in the college the change will be rolled out to all our users but even then we can't influence our users when they are at home. Sorry this is a bit wordy - I do hope it helps with your immediate problem. P.S. This is not a Moodle problem - you would hit the same problem with the presentations on any server

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PowerPoint Slideshow
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mary and Dave, After posting I had a look around other forums and as you suggested, this is a genital problem, probably related to Internet Explorer.  I have converted them to .html multipage files; surprisingly it seems to work very well. They open with a navigation bar on LHS with slide titles, as with PowerPoint files, but if you click on "Slideshow" in bottom RH of status bar, a full screen slideshow opens in a new window. Thanks again. Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Directory resources with toolbar
ResponsesInList.Text: I have users who want to print resources and since Word docs appear in a popup with no toolbar, they're SOL. Near as I can tell, it must be in the Modules/View file somewhere around line 500andsomething: link_to_popup_window($relativeurl, "resourceedirectory$resource->id", "$file", 450, 600, ''); What would I need to add to this to have the popup have the toolbar, or even better, how do I change things so Directory/File resources show up embedded instead of in popup windows? Thanks! Sarah

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Directory resources with toolbar
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this works... Edit lib/weblib.php at about line 319 (I'm on v1.4.1, may be a slightly different line number for other versions). It looks like: function link_to_popup_window ($url, $name="popup", $linkname="click here", $height=400, $width=500, $title="Popup window", $options="none", $return=false) { /// This will create a HTML link that will work on both /// Javascript and non-javascript browsers. /// Relies on the Javascript function openpopup in javascript.php /// $url must be relative to home page  eg /mod/survey/stuff.php global $CFG; if ($options == "none") { $options = "menubar=0,location=0,scrollbars,resizable,width=$width,height=$height"; } $fullscreen = 0; $link = " wwwroot $url\" ". "onClick=\"return openpopup('$url', '$name', '$options', $fullscreen);\">$linkname\n"; if ($return) { return $link; } else { you need to change that red highlighted bit to: global $CFG; if ($options == "none") { $options = "menubar= 1 ,location=0,scrollbars,resizable,width=$width,height=$height"; } $fullscreen = 0; if you want a menu bar (which should allow users to select File > Save or File > Print) and change it to global $CFG; if ($options == "none") { $options = "menubar= 1 ,location= 1 ,scrollbars,resizable,width=$width,height=$height"; } $fullscreen = 0; if you want the document's address to be displayed in the location bar. This works on my local instance of Moodle, am just about to try it on my production server ...

ResponsesInList.Title: 2.4.3 Save button would be nice Add'n
ResponsesInList.Text: When developing page resources, sometimes, you just need to write, preview, rewrite, ...etc. The current choices at the bottom of the page resource are Save and Return, and Save and Display. There is no button just labelled Save.  Since Save and Display won't run an external macros (like links to MathJax), you can't preview TeX formatted math with that display.  "Save and return" means that you need to return to the main page and in order to return to editing, you must find the small gear icon after scrolling back down to the point in the class that has the assignment. With modern, multi-tab browsers, its time for just a save button.  Then someone in the process of editing and testing would just need to save then then switch to the tab already displaying the page and hit F5.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Filenames with Non-ascii Characters Running IIS 7.5 and 7
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone I struck on a problem today with file names, which contains specific danish characters (æøå). At first a thought this might be an issue with encoding, however the problem lies outside Moodle. After having debugging I found that the function ressource_pluginfile contains a varible called args, wich gets the filename in the URI. If running an IIS with Fast CGI any non ascii characters will be cut of, which will result in Moodle not being able to return the file to the user (file not found error). Microsoft has issue a hotfix for this error, which can be found at following URLs: IIS 7.5 : http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2277918/ IIS 7.0 : http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?displaylang=en&FamilyID=c17a72bd-7009-4830-85e0-06290f3b8367 More information about this issue can be seen at http://www.redolivedesign.com/utah-web-designers-blog/2010/10/18/how-to-fix-utf-8charset-problem-with-iis-7-5-and-php-fastcgi/ I hope this post will help others fix the issue, without going through hours of debugging. Best regards /Henrik

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ResourcePage Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, thanks for trying it. Unfortunately, as noted on the download page for resourcepage, it currently requires the Postgres database, not MySQL . This might cause these problems (and others if you get past that stage). Database table creation is all done using the Moodle cross-platform system but some of the queries use Postgres-specific features (well, mostly SQL standard features, but whatever) that are not supported in MySQL. I have edited the description to make this clearer. It's in bold now! And in a clear list. (Before it was just one sentence towards the end in normal type, so it was a bit easy to miss.) We are hoping to enhance resourcepages to also support MySQL, perhaps in the next few months (I can't promise a date! or even that we actually get it done. but it looks hopeful). If using Postgres is not an option for you, then maybe you can try again then. Apologies for the inconvenience. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ResourcePage Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sam Thanks for replying. It's a real shame, I guess the majority of Moodlers use MySQL. I had a quick look and I don't think Postgres would be easy for us to transfer to. (Has anyone out there transfered from MySQL to Postgres???? Is there major benefits in transfering?) How much work do you estimate there is in making ResourcePage MySQL compatible? Many thanks again Joe

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ResourcePage Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: I wish this was in MySql too, we really need a module like this but can't use Postgres

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ResourcePage Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: The problem is a few of the SQL statements in the code. Fixing it would involve searching all the resourcepage code for "->do_sql", and checking that the SQL there works in MySQL. There will only be a few that are a problem (unfortunately they will be the most complex), and the first task is to identify them, then the second task is to rewrite them in a database-independent way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot open files higher that 1 MB
ResponsesInList.Text: Miguel, you probably need to change your "Maximum Upload Size" file size settings. You can change this by clicking Settings which you should be to the left on your main screen under Administration. This will allow you to Edit Course Settings. Then scroll down until you see maximum upload file size....then simply change the file size to a much larger file. Hopefully that will solve your problem. Angie DiLillo

ResponsesInList.Title: File Download stall outs with Snow Leopard
ResponsesInList.Text: I thought I'd try asking the excellent Moodle community about this even though it is probably only indirectly related to Moodle but we are seeing students having issues downloading files from Moodle under the following conditions: OS: Mac OS 10.6 "Snow Leopard" Browser: Either Firefox or Safari Connection: Offsite ( a slower connection than LAN speed) Basically, any Macbooks with Snow Leopard on them have trouble downloading files (through a resources module) that are greater than 1MB if they are offsite no matter what browser they use (if they are on Campus the files come through just fine). What happens is the download starts and then gets to 1MB and just stops (stalls out). No error, no nothing. You can try to resume, etc and the same thing happens over and over again. When I look in the Apache access logs I see a successful hit on the file.php URL (200) and exactly 1MB of data sent (almost like the browser sent an ACK command saying they were done). I've checked into all of our time-out settings and nothing seems very low (in fact, the downloads hit 1MB and stop pretty quickly before a time-out could possibly be triggered it seems). The other oddity is that they can go to a non-Moodle section of our portal with a file download repository (just straight URLs, no fancy send_file calls or chunking) during the same session and those files will download flawlessly. So, it seems like it is some combo of how Moodle does file downloading and how Snow Leopard receives files. Any help would be appreciated as I have found nothing on the subject and the number of students who can't access files offsite is mounting. The specs: Moodle 1.9.3+ is running on Windows 2003 with MySQL 5.0.21, Apache 2.0.58 and PHP 5.2.3 The site is running as pure SSL and we have all files forced to download (we've had display problems in Safari and Firefox with some embedded file types).

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi If you can't increase it from moodle administration, it is certainly that you need to change settings in your php.ini files..Look for "post_max_size" and "upload_max_filesize" in the server 's apache/bin folder. Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Editing existing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: We use moodle 1 mostly to organise resources so students can access them easily. Resources are mostly MS-Word documents but also MS-Excel, PDF, html etc. It takes a long time to update a resource doesn’t it! Delete existing resource. Upload new one from local machine. Very tedious. We found a way to access the files directly, which means we can edit and save them directly on the moodle server . Updates are ‘live’ as soon as the new version is saved. (Basically, we can use Windows Explorer to open the moodle server folder like any other file folder). I understand that with moodle 2 this will not be possible. I don’t think I’ll be using moodle now because it takes too long to update existing resources. If I open a file through moodle, it is always read-only – even if it’s a file I wrote and uploaded myself. Why?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing existing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: With Moodle 2.3 you have a variety of ways of editing  exisiting documents. For example upload your Word document into your Private files and then link to it in your courses. Update it just in your private files and it will automatically update elsewhere Use an external file sharing site like Box.net repository or Dropbox and again when you update in one of those, it will automatically update on your Moodle. No need to reupload. Moodle 2.3 is much better than Moodle 1 in that respect. See http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Working_with_files#Creating_an_alias.2Fshortcut

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mass email
ResponsesInList.Text: One way to do this is through forced subscription to a Forum.  For course teachers, have them subscribe to the "Teacher forum" within the course and then simply make a post of the message you want them to receive.  For students, set the "News Forum" on the course homepage to Force everyone to be subcribed?: , and then make a post as mentioned.  If your annoucement e-mail to students is for the entire site (ie, all courses), use the Site News forum on Moodle homepage and set to forced subscription.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Major resource error with internet explorer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing Frame Option?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Yes, there is ( moodle 1.5.3+ ): In the file .../mod/resource/type/file/resource.class.php erase the five letters marked yellow in the following code segment (near the end of the file): 
```text
        $windowtype = ($CFG->resource_popup) ? 'popup' : 'page';
```
 
```text
        if (empty($form->options)) {
```
 
```text
            $form->options = '
frame
';
```
 
```text
            $form->reference = $CFG->resource_defaulturl;
```
 
```text
        }
```
 
```text
    }
```
 This will change the default of new file resources to "unchecked" while retaining the ability to turn the option on again. Regards, Klaus

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML. text and link pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Any resource must be setup in a course. As a result, the 'course_module' table id is used to call the resource not the 'resource' table. The 'resource' table ids are the "instance" of the module which is included in the 'course_module' table. The best way to discover the proper URL is to launch it from within the course that was used to create it and note the address in the address bar. Simply paste this as your target from anywhere within Moodle and the course and module will be called up. The user must be enrolled in the course to view the resource. I set up a general course with unrestricted access to setup and host these types of resources. Regarding pop-ups. I use the resource setting to launch in a new window. This seems to be a very reliable way to launch resources from anywhere in Moodle in a popup window. However, the main window will navigate to the hosting course. I hope this helps. Jamie

I've partly resolved the problem by  creating files systematically so that ID's are in sequence...saves a bit of time having to launch new pop-ups to get the ID. Thanks also for the explanation of how the database works. Dave

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Linking a new page
ResponsesInList.Text: Well you could use the main menu block - with the editing turned on, add a block and choose main menu. Then use th "compose a webpage" feature in there to make your pages. get the URLS of the pages and copy them somewhere like notepad. Then hide with the eye the main menu block - the pages will still be accessible via their URL . You can make hyperlinks to your pages. on your front page -I would do it via an HTML block (add a block etc). There are some themes you can download that give you tabs you could customise with your own links but if you want to do it within standard Moodle then that is how I would do it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Resource: Text bug in Moodle 1.7 fix
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Today I tried to use a text resource on my Moodle homepage to provide information to visitors. It turnes out that the content is only displayed if the resource is configured as pop-up or without blocks. So I inserted the following lines into resource.class.php under mod/resource/type/text line 91: $course = $this->course; line 92: $resource = $this->resource; line 101: echo format_text($resource->alltext, $resource->options, $formatoptions, $course->id); (this is in the section /// Are we displaying the course blocks?) Hope someone fixes this in the released code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Its possible to create a resource inside another resource ?
ResponsesInList.Text: I Need to create the following hierarchy: My Moodle -> Course -> Main Resource -> Second Resource -> 3rd Resource So navigation bar can display the full path of a resource, its that possible ? Tks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Its possible to create a resource inside another resource ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kirk, Jordan's just asked me to have a look at this for you, he also informs me you are using Moodle 1.9. Within Moodle it is not possible to create one resource inside another. You can add resources and activities to a course and that is it. If what you are really after is just the navigation bar then you could probably hack the build_navigation function within weblib.php to alter the navigation bar based upon the order of activities/resources within a course section, and then indent the activities/resources within the section to fake the appearance, however it would require changing core core so would probably not be a great idea. Hope this helps. Cheers Sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Its possible to create a resource inside another resource ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Looks like a "possible" solution, wich is better that what i have so far, sry to ask that much, but could you show me some code for making it work ? So far all i know is that the build_navigation is on weblib.php. I allready have my resources in order and Indented when i list my course resources, how can I put this on build_navigation? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Its possible to create a resource inside another resource ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kirk, Presently I'm flat tack at work so can't stop to look too much into it however at a glance I would suggest trying the following. I see that build_navigation takes a $cm object and part way through the function it checks if its an object and then adds stuff to the navigation. I would think that $cm contains both the course id and section id/number which should be enough for what you need. To begin I would use the course id to retrieve the course (which is likely $COURSE) and then call $modinfo = get_fast_modinfo($course) with it to get all of the information about the resources/activities in the course. Within $modinfo you will need to locate the section that the $cm is within and then iterate through its activities/resources adding each to the $navlinks array stopping when you get to the end OR you find the activity/resource that matches $cm's instanceid. It sounds a little complex but when you plan it out it shouldn't be too bad. That being said you will probably need pretty good development skills to get through it. Sorry I can't help more at this point hopefully the above is enough to get you through, all focus is on Moodle 2.0 development presently. Cheers Sam

ResponsesInList.Text: Im not familiar with moodle functions, ive got the $modinfo = get_fast_modinfo($COUSE)  but i have no idea how to iterate this getting the resources, im pretty shure that moodle have some function for that but no idea wich one...

ResponsesInList.Title: Content Security
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello All, I'm facing a problem regarding my course security which is running in moodle. I want to make my content secure to copy purpose , so that noone can copy my content and flash swf's. Can this is possible in moodle ??

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Content Security
ResponsesInList.Text: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=67649

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Content Security
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Amit, The short answer is no, you can't protect your SWF files from being copied when they are displayed using Moodle. There are ways to make it more difficult but ultimately, anyone can install one of the many plugins for Firefox that'll circumvent any security measures that you introduce. Basically, Flash is inherently insecure as it's very easy to download , copy and decompile (read the Actionscript code). The only thing that I can think of, off the top of my head, is to embed your SWF files in secure PDF files. I believe that Adobe Acrobat allows you to do this from version 8 (or earlier?) onwards. The PDF would be encrypted and fairly secure but nothing's 100%! Also, don't be conned into buying SWF Actionscript encryption applications. All they are is obfuscators which only serve to make the code more difficult to read. A very simple security measure you can include is for the SWF to check the URL it's on before it runs the program. So if anyone downloads and copies to another location, it won't run. You can also configure it to show a copyright message and give a link to your website. But again, anyone can decompile your SWF and change the code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: File Activity - possible to add a button when users reaches bottom of document?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ted, I used to use PDF's but switched to using Book resources for a couple of reasons. One, PDF's were much more time consuming and awkward to edit and update. Two, there was no simple way to create a link/path to another PDF, reading assignment, or directions. Using Book's had multiple advantages. I could edit, if needed, right in Moodle. I could break up long PDF's by splitting into chapters and sub-chapters. And the one you need, I could enter HTML links that would take my students directly to the next needed location in the course. Just go to the location I wanted to go to, copy the URL , go to the point in the book where I wanted to jump from, insert the URL link, then save the book. In many cases, I would have multiple links since I taught 7th and 8th graders, and depending on the grade of the student, they would need to jump to different places, sometimes.

It would be helpful to know what version of php you are running. Can you upload files to your server? Create a file called something obscure like testfile.php (must be "something.php") and include this line: <?php info.php ?> Upload it to your webroot and then in your browser go to yourwebsite.com/testfile.php to see what version of php you are running. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: errors in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: There shouldn't be any conflict with your version of Moodle and the version of PHP you are using. It's really difficult to say not knowing what may have happened during the migration. Your system may be suffering from multiple issues here, Is it possible that these errors exited before but you had error reporting set differently? Do you have access to the last working instance of the site? Do you have the CD with the code you gave to your hosting company? For what it is worth, what I would do is: try to install a copy of the original site on my local computer (I use xampp on Mac and Windows for this) Set error reporting to full power (Site Administration > Server > Debugging > DEVELOPER) This way you get maximum error reporting. See what you get Download the latest version of Moodle and update your local version (remember to include all your 3rd-party module with the upgrade - refer to google docs for more help on upgrading) One other thing: check that you have sufficient server memory allocated for your installation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Subtitles aren't available in Youtube URL resouce
ResponsesInList.Text: I have added a YouTube link with URL resource in my lesson . Despite subtitles are available in the youtube, when I view the video from my course there is none option to select a subtitle. Is there a solution to that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subtitles aren't available in Youtube URL resouce
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello John, Solution 1 I don't think the control bar provided by Moodle has a button to toggle subtitles on and off. However, subtitles can be displayed by default. Here's how: Go to Youtube. Edit your video. At the bottom of the "Video Details" page, click "VIEW MORE". In the "Add tag" box, add "yt:cc=on". Save your video. The subtitles will then be displayed in the video. Note that it takes a few seconds before the control bar fades away and the subtitles become clearly visible. Solution 2 Otherwise, users can open the video in YouTube by simply clicking in the upper part of the video. In YouTube, the control bar includes a button to enable and disable subtitles.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subtitles aren't available in Youtube URL resouce
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the info!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subtitles aren't available in Youtube URL resouce
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much for this! Solution 1 worked for me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subtitles aren't available in Youtube URL resouce
ResponsesInList.Text: Click Settings . From the left-hand menu, click Playback and performance. Check or uncheck Always show captions. Check or uncheck Include auto-generated captions (when available). ______________________________________________________________________________________ See: https://subdl.live/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Backups del sitio
ResponsesInList.Text: Creo que es mejor tomar responsabilidad por los backups como administrador y no utilizar las capacidades por dentro de Moodle para hacer lo mismo. Asi, recomiendo pensar del proceso de hacer un backup como la Santa Trinidad (tres partes distintas en uno) que uno se debe practicar religiosamente (por lo menos diaramente). Las partes consisten en 1) un backup del base de archivos utilizando una herramienta como MySQL Admin para exportar los datos a un archivo de formato SQL 2) hacer una copia de todos los archivos en la carpeta de MoodleData y 3) ultimamente, hacer una copia de los archivos que consisten su instalación de Moodle, quiere decir el código (especialmente el archivo config.php). Con los archivos de MoodleData, despues de archivar todos los archivos me parece aceptable hacer un backup parcial de solo los archivos que han cambiado pero cada semana haria otro backup completo. Al respeto del número 3 es importante si uno ha aplicado cambios especializados para su sitio. Si se usa del programa como es pues siempre es posible bajarlo de nuevo del internet. Con estes tres pedazitos, se puede reconstruir su sitio. Espero que este responde a la pregunta y no le ha dejado con mas preguntas. Suerte y feliz Moodle-ando - Antonio

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems locating style that is applying background-color
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Glenn, It was good to see you again at this year's MADLaT conference. Here's the link to CSS inspector I use when doing Moodle Themes : http://www.moddular.org/log/css-inspector/ . It's very helpful. Jody.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems locating style that is applying background-color
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Glen, When you say "a HTML resource page" do you mean (1) an HTML page composed on your computer using e.g. a web page editor, then uploaded to "my files" directory on your Moodle site, OR (2) an HTML page composed directly on the Moodle platform, inserted using the drop-down box "Add a Resource" -> "Compose a Web page"? Which theme are you using? a standard Moodle theme? out of the box or customized? In case you mean (2) above, you can add the following to one of your current theme's CSS files: 
```text
.mod-resource #page #content .generalbox {


  background-color: #FFFFFF; /* = white */


}
```
 Hope this helps, Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sharing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Noel, If your system is LINUX, the best way to achieve your goal is to create a symbolic link from your external resource repository to the individual folder id for the course accessing the resources.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sharing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: how do I do that? Is it possible to link to my moodledata folder which is outside of my public_html? Noel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sharing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Noel - Have you tried using the "Glossary" tool to create an image database ? If you create a glossary and flag it as "global" then it's available to all courses. Additionally, if you set the glossary type to "Encyclopedia", then when you create glossary entries with images as attachments, they are automatically displayed inline, so it becomes a very neat images database with keyword searching, autolinking, and other nice features.

ResponsesInList.Title: Sharing resources esp. images
ResponsesInList.Text: If you create a glossary and flag it as "global" then it's available to all courses That's what I thought as well and IMO that's how it should be. But especially if you are including pictures this doesn't work. It's like Dan said in his other post: file.php handles permissions very strictly and as such if you are not enrolled in the course to which the glossary belongs (even if it's a global one), you will not have access to the pictures in it: they will not display. I agree with Dan that hacking file.php to take away some of the security is a dangerous thing. But how about this: file.php checks if you are logged in (course doesn't matter) file.php only serves images / no other filetypes file.php only serves images that are inside a directory called `public` or `sitewide` to make sure no teacher puts files in there which should be available to students of a particular course only.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sharing resources
ResponsesInList.Text: P.S. Try not to violate Moodle's security by fiddling around with symbolic links directly to the moodledata folder! The reason for putting the moodledata folder outside the public_html directory is because the folder is readable/writeable by the server, and therefore if it was remotely accessible there is a security risk. Moodle handles access security through things like file.php which checks authorisation before sending out files taken from the moodledata folder.

ResponsesInList.Title: .flv resource revisited
ResponsesInList.Text: Let me try explaining this again: We are upgrading from Moodle 1.9 to 2.1.  Many courses have .flv resource links.  These links to not work after the upgrade.  Moodle seens not to know what to do with them. If I edit them through the browser and put something in the Intro field and change them from popup to automatic they work fine.  I can make these changes to the mdl_resource table behind the scenes with 1 simple SQL command, but I still need to edit the resource (just open and save it) to make the resource link work. Is there any way to touch some table behind the scenes so course owners do not have to do this final hand edit of all there .flv links. Thanks a lot...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: .flv resource revisited
ResponsesInList.Text: This may not help much. I set up my first Moodle with 2.0 and had problems because my videos were class length. I had to load them directly into the foldler on the server via the backend. Apparently the answer is that 2.0 and higher uses a different file structure to store the vid files. They are not stored in the folder where they used to be. Therefore, when Moodle goes to find the video...they are in the "wrong" place. Thus, your popup is looking in the wrong place. You either have to get your files in the right place and/or direct your popup to the right folder. I hope that points you in the right direction. Dan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: .flv resource revisited
ResponsesInList.Text: Yeah, my problem isn't knowing where the .flv files are.  Moodle knows where they are.  All I have to do is tweek the record for the link - add the missing intro text and set the type to automatic, and it works great.  My problem is automating this task so that course administrators don't have to do a simple GUI edit task over and over again after the upgrade. By the way, it's not just the video files that are stored differently under 2.0+ - all files are stored in a proprietary setup.  The former moodledata directories corresponding to the course ids are all empty.  It has moved to prorpietary files in the filedata directory.  Now everything must be accessed through the database and/or program code.  I think the developers did this in an attempt to improve overall data integrity. : ) Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: String for "Resources" in the breadcrumbs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, where does Moodle (>= 1.8.2) get the string which is displayed in the breadcrumbs for what it calls "resources"? It doesn't seem to take it from the moodle.php lang file. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: String for "Resources" in the breadcrumbs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, I got it myself. The strings in the breadcrumbs are the module names . So they are not taken from the "moodle.php" lang file, but from the "resource.php" lang file! (Changing the "resource" and "resources" string in moodle.php isn't what helps.) Should anyone else drop to the same question sometime, here a short " howto ": Prerequisite: The web server process (apache or whatever) must have write permission to this file on the server Login as admin Goto >Administration >Language >Language editing Choose in the dropdown menu "Current language" the language for which you want to change the string Click on "Edit Strings" Choose the "resource.php" lang file Search the variables "modulename" and "modulenameplural" in the displayed variables of the file Change in the field at the right the string to whatever you want to Don't forget to click "Save changes: resource.php"

ResponsesInList.Title: Change the default pdf files drag & drop into PDF.js files
ResponsesInList.Text:
```text
In Moodle 2.9 platform, we use the 
https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_pdfjsfolder
 Module

In the course home page , if a file with a .pdf extension is added by using the " drag and drop" , create a pdfjsfolder resource in the section in which we do drag and drop.
The title of the resource will be the name of the PDF file.
We must create a resource for each added PDF.

If the file has another extension, other than .pdf , add the file as the default mode of Moodle.

If possible, add these modifications in a custom plugin in / local
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a contributed resource type named 'Label Collapsed' ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=190563 ). It enables to create label that can be expanded and collapsed on the page. This feature has been appreciated by a number of users, so I thought it might be worth to integrate this functionality in to a standard Label resource as an option within settings. Therefore, I would like to see what do others think about that. I am thinking of spending some time on that and would like to check if it would be worth it. I have opened an issue on tracker in advance: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-43336

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: I think anything that has the potential to clean up the page is promising.  As long as it is just an option - I think that most of us promote the label as a way to post information that we want students to be aware of and would not want them missing it because it was minimized.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this would be ok with most people, but I think they would probably desire there to be a dropdown box that you chose one of these three options from: Standard (Non-Collapsible)  {This item would never have a +/- } Collapsible, initially Expanded {This item would have a +/- } Collapsible, initially Collapsed {This item would have a +/- } As Emma mentioned, I put some important stuff in labels that I don't want there to even be a way to collapse it and somehow the student miss it (or use the collapsibility as an excuse). Also while discussing labels, I would also REALLY like labels and item descriptions that show on the main page to be editable on the mainpage!  This seems in the spirit of allowing us to rename resources and activities directly on the main page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: As Emma mentioned, I put some important stuff in labels that I don't want there to even be a way to collapse it and somehow the student miss it (or use the collapsibility as an excuse). But then you would be able to choose something like 'collapsable: false' within the settings, wouldn't you? The resource already exists, the thing I propose is to merge the functionality with the original Label resource with no harm to users. I agree that inline editing would be great.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have now created a patch implementing this feature and submitted it to Moodle Tracker ( https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-43336 ). Please feel free to take a look if you want to!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add a setting for a label resource to be collapsable
ResponsesInList.Text: It seems that this feature didn't catch any attention of anyone, though it is a really handy one. Maybe it I update this thread, someone will notice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Passing URL variable to Google Form

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Passing URL variable to Google Form
ResponsesInList.Text: Solution: you need to find out what the Google Form Field ID's are. To do that, choose pre-filled responses and examine the link so you can find out what the field ID in the Google Form is. They're something like "entry.3432423." Take those and use them in the &parameter=variable section in Moodle URL.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Extreme slowness with Folders.
ResponsesInList.Text: They're at 2.6.1+, hosted on Ubuntu LTS 12 with 6 gig of ram on a VM . VM server has juice, and there's never been any real slowdown before, with or without opcode caching. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Extreme slowness with Folders.
ResponsesInList.Text: On the course level, only the resource info is displayed, so the actual content of folders (files and subfolders) should have no bearing on performance. It might be worth checking the server logs (with debugging cranked up) and whether this has any relation to the theme and/or course format used.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WebMail in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hana - Let's see if we can get that issue fixed. I am going to see if I can find someone more familiar with webmail to comment. I think quickmail would be your best bet so let's work to file an issue in the tracker and get it fixed. Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WebMail in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hana: You might find "quickmail for large classes" (aka quickmail v2) lightweighted and super fast. We use it (and developed) here at SFSU. I'm not that familiar with the sticky block feature so I will have to test it out with quickmail v2. I'm hoping that somehow I could find some time to finish my quickmail v2 enhancement project so that it would be fully compatible with the new 1.9 and 2.0 codebases. Currently it should work with 1.9.x codes with minor known issues (such as we intentionally disabled the GROUP support in v2). Hope this helps! Cheers!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WebMail in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hanaa! We use the eMail Block , sometimes called eMail List. As you probably know, there aren't a lot of options out there for Moodle internal mail. For us, it was between the eMail block and Quickmail. I can't specifically remember why eMail List won out, but we've had no problems with it. The folder and contacts organization and functions are not as user-friendly as I would like, but that it from an Admin point of few. For teachers and students with only a handfull of courses, I'm sure its much easier to work with.
